meanings.def: having a lot of physical power so that you can lift heavy weights, do hard physical work, etc.
examples: He's strong enough to lift a car!
strong muscles
She wasn't a strong swimmer (= she could not swim well).

meanings.def: having great power
examples: Stay indoors in the middle of the day, when the sun is strongest.
a strong wind
a strong magnet/current

meanings.def: having a powerful effect on the body or mind
examples: a strong drug
His imagery made a strong impression on the critics.

meanings.def: having a lot of power or influence
examples: a strong leader
What the country needs right now is a strong government.
The party lacks a strong enough local base.
She is the leader of one of the country's strongest trade unions.
The report recommended a strong role for the governing board in school policy on discipline.
Will this damage his image as a strong leader?

meanings.def: people who are rich or powerful
difficult to attack or criticize
examples: There is strong evidence of a link between exercise and a healthy heart.
You have a strong case for getting your job back.

meanings.def: very powerful and difficult for people to fight against or defeat
examples: a strong team
The proposal aroused strong opposition.
The temptation to tell her everything was very strong.
He exerts an extremely strong influence on his classmates.

meanings.def: very powerful
examples: strong support for the government
People have strong feelings about this issue.

meanings.def: holding an opinion or a belief very seriously
examples: a strong supporter of the government
a strong opponent
She has long been one of the strongest advocates of sanctions.

meanings.def: easy to see, hear, feel or smell; very great or intense
examples: a strong smell
a strong feeling of nausea
a strong voice (= loud)
strong colours
a face with strong features (= large and easy to notice)
She spoke with a strong Australian accent.
He was under strong pressure to resign.

meanings.def: having a lot of taste
examples: strong cheese
You'll need to use plenty of strong French mustard.

meanings.def: containing a lot of a substance
examples: strong black coffee

meanings.def: not easily broken or damaged; made well
examples: The box looks strong enough.

meanings.def: not easily upset or frightened; not easily influenced by other people
examples: You need strong nerves to ride a bike in London.
Every child needs to develop a strong sense of identity.
It's difficult, I know. But be strong!
a strong personality
She’s had a strong will since she was a baby.
We must stand strong in the face of adversity.

meanings.def: likely to succeed or happen
examples: a strong candidate for the job
You're in a strong position to negotiate a deal.
There's a strong possibility that we'll lose the game.

meanings.def: having existed for a long time and functioning well; difficult to destroy
examples: a strong marriage
The college has strong links with local industry.
I know that their relationship is growing stronger every day.

meanings.def: having a value that is high or increasing
examples: strong share prices
The country is currently experiencing particularly strong economic growth.
The euro is getting stronger against the dollar.
This news helped keep the dollar relatively strong today.

meanings.def: in a safe financial position
examples: Their catering business remained strong despite the recession.

meanings.def: good at something; done well
examples: The play has a very strong cast.
The actors give extremely strong performances.
Mathematics was never my strong point (= I was never very good at it).

meanings.def: great in number
examples: There was a strong police presence at the demonstration.
Sales were surprisingly strong in the second half of the year.

meanings.def: used after numbers to show the size of a group
examples: a 5 000-strong crowd
The crowd was 5 000 strong.

meanings.def: not easily affected by disease; healthy
examples: These vitamins are meant to keep you healthy and strong.
I’m not feeling very well.
Is he well enough to travel?
Are you feeling all right?
She says she’s OK now, and will be back at work tomorrow.
‘How are you?’ ‘Fine, thanks.’
Keep healthy by exercising regularly.
After a few weeks she was feeling stronger.
I go swimming every day in order to keep fit.
Are you feeling stronger now after your rest?
We hope to see you well and strong again soon.

meanings.def: having a lot of force, often causing offence to people
examples: The movie has been criticized for strong language (= swearing).

meanings.def: forming the past tense and past participle by changing a vowel, not by adding a regular ending, for example sing, sang, sung
used to describe the way some words are pronounced when they have stress. For example, the strong form of and is /ænd/.
used to say that you think what somebody has said is unfair or too critical
something that gives somebody an advantage over other people in a particular situation
to be good at something
examples: I'm not very strong on dates (= I can't remember the dates of important events).

meanings.def: to have a lot of something
examples: The report was strong on criticism, but short on practical suggestions.

meanings.def: to be a subject that somebody knows a lot about
examples: I'm afraid geography is not my strong suit.

meanings.def: to make your feelings clear in an aggressive way, especially your sexual feelings towards somebody
to continue to be healthy, active or successful
examples: My grandmother is 90 and still going strong.
The business is still going strong.

meanings.def: to be able to see or do unpleasant things without feeling sick or upset
examples: You need a strong stomach to go on the giant roller coaster.

idioms.def: used to say that you think what somebody has said is unfair or too critical
something that gives somebody an advantage over other people in a particular situation

examples: I'm not very strong on dates (= I can't remember the dates of important events).
The report was strong on criticism, but short on practical suggestions.

idioms.def: to be a subject that somebody knows a lot about
examples: I'm afraid geography is not my strong suit.

idioms.def: to make your feelings clear in an aggressive way, especially your sexual feelings towards somebody
to continue to be healthy, active or successful
examples: My grandmother is 90 and still going strong.
The business is still going strong.

idioms.def: to be able to see or do unpleasant things without feeling sick or upset
examples: You need a strong stomach to go on the giant roller coaster.
